emphasize is - you got to give yourself a chance to succeed you got to give yourself a worthwhile shot and don't

bit - before we started to pitch feces a lot of folks are always interested in well okay I have an idea I want to do a

successful entrepreneur who's been really successful because they had an idea they're successful because they
being able to execute on the idea so a lot of young entrepreneurs I've talked

no one can see my baby but like all babies babies love running around naked that's all they want to do and so your

grow in a vacuum ideas only improve if you get feedback and so when we had the
idea for me beau it was through a long series of failures and I'll go over that but we asked everybody what they thought
because if you don't ask you're never gonna find out right and so like I said
the idea is not unique because many people have that idea but it's how you craft the idea how you improve upon it
how you work on it how you grow it that's really important and when ideas

god you're crazy why are you doing that that's never gonna work or why are you quitting your job pursue your silly startup and what's special about here is
Silicon Valley and Stanford in this community is that people here tell you how to improve the idea they riff on it

it encourages you to sort of follow the unbeaten path or go nuts on some weird

there's college and so I didn't really had no time off since high school so I took the opportunity to watch like a lot

and kind of you know we said and some months past I was like well should I do another shot

wanted to have more impact I you know really needed to sort of just reset
figure out what I wanted to do and so when my current co-founders of honor freed up we you know kind of regrouped

is as a second or third time entrepreneur you have a lot more experience obviously because you've done a lot and you have better tuned
instincts then the first time around and as first-time entrepreneurs which I
think a lot of you would like to be the excitement of being an entrepreneur it's kind of like a shot of adrenaline so
it's third of the sustained adrenaline shot that kind of like rides you through the first startup because you're just
like full of energy full of enthusiasm you can work like 40 million hours a week and you're just like crazy and
later on that it definitely kind of wears out but the adrenaline is replaced by you know sort of more efficient
muscles you know better thinking a little bit more pause when you act and a lot more
experience which is actually really helpful and for the the second startup
it was actually a big deal to decide to jump back in and the reason I say this is that you know the average they say
the average lifetime of a startup is about seven years so if you're gonna think about doing a start-up and really committing to it you should really
commit seven years that's usually like seven years till some sort of you know exit event or whether it dies or

trading off social time family time you know personal time to really commit
yourself to this venture because ultimately you're responsible for your team the product you're you know you

gonna jump back in we kind of had these sort of like stipulations of as the
first-time entrepreneur Meebo was really exciting it was really cool is you know social media esque stuff but it didn't
have like the world impact that I think and honor had and when I wanted to do it
again I really wanted more impact I was hungry or I was prettier for you know to make a bigger

us got together and we're like okay we're really picky what do we want to do and so we decided that we need to meet

picked a small tiny market like people who liked purple cars like that's a really tiny fit so the demographic that
I can work with as opposed to senior care which which can affect people worldwide so huge market the second idea
of the second it's for stipulation was it really had to help people right like I can I can argue how meebo you know in

wanted something that I could look you in the eye and be like I made your life better and then the third one which is
interesting is that we wanted it to be an execution risk and so the way we think about it and this sort of
framework was my co-founder came up with which I think really resonated with all of us which was think about a spectrum

the world really ache for a messaging platform that had messages that expired after three seconds I don't know like
who knows like I have no distinct advantage over all of you to figure out what that what I thought that would work so there's this sort of market risk of
wool if I build it like will they come and on the other end the spectrum there's if I build it execution risk
well I build it they will definitely come but it's really friggin hard to build and so we wanted this end of the
spectrum because I have no we have no inherent advantages over folks like you who understand like what eighteen year
olds want on their cell phones I have no idea oh my god the type of wood that's speeded what you guys text is amazing
but on this side like I had a lot of a lot of sort of experience I knew how to
operate I knew how to hire I knew how to get resources we had connections in the BC space I
could get funding and so we really wanted to skew this way and so if you
sort of think about all three of those criteria we kind of listed like giant problems in the world like unemployment
poverty education child care senior care we even joked that we could like get a
VC to give us money to buy out a third world country and fix it we had two
grand aspirations but then we all to me decide we didn't want to move to a third world country so we kind of killed that idea but that was the scale at which we

of keyed us in on the on the senior space and so when we kind of started to dig and dig and dig it was turned out

had made a lot of mistakes at me beau I first find mantras you don't know what you're doing you're learning as you do you're in the deep end of the pool

exciting for me to learn from my past mistakes and one of the interesting
things was that during the Google acquisition for me beau during the last
